etymologies: mid 17th century (denoting a muscle): modern Latin, from Latin elevare ‘raise’; in later use directly from elevate

crossReferenceMarkers: British term lift (sense 1 of the noun)
definitions: a platform or compartment housed in a shaft for raising and lowering people or things to different floors or levels.

examples.text: in the elevator she pressed the button for the lobby

definitions: a machine consisting of an endless belt with scoops attached, used typically for raising grain to be stored in an upper story.
a tall building used for storing large quantities of grain

examples.text: in the harbor a giant elevator stores prairie grain

definitions: a hinged flap on the horizontal stabilizer of an aircraft, typically one of a pair, used to control the motion of the aircraft about its lateral axis

examples.text: first you trim the rudder, then the ailerons, and finally the elevator

definitions: a muscle whose contraction raises a part of the body
a shoe with a raised insole designed to make the wearer appear taller

examples.text: something in his gait made me sure he was wearing elevator shoes
